tossups.question: This composer had a piccolo quote the Andante movement of one of his own symphonies during an aria about a ploughman in spring. Another choral piece by this composer opens in C minor with a loud, held tutti C before a quiet, harmonically ambiguous flattened submediant triad. Later in that piece by this composer, soft pizzicato strings precede a loud, radiant C major chord on the word “Licht,” or (*) “Light.” Gottfried van Swieten (“SVEE-tin”) wrote the libretto for this composer’s The Seasons, as well as his oratorio beginning with a “Representation of Chaos” depicting the early universe. A timpani stroke in bar 16 of the second movement accompanies a sudden dynamic change in this composer’s Symphony No. 94 in G major, written in London. For 10 points, name this composer of The Creation and the “Surprise” Symphony.
tossups.answer: Joseph Haydn [or Franz Joseph Haydn] <WA, Classical/Opera>

tossups.question: A passage in this novel compares love to the sea, since “it’s uh movin’ thing” and “it’s different with every shore.” This novel opens by noting how “the Watcher turns his eyes away in resignation” while describing “Ships at a distance [that] have every man’s wish on board.” In this novel, which was written while its author was on a Guggenheim fellowship in Haiti, the protagonist exclaims “So this was a marriage!” as she muses on a blossoming (*) pear tree at the age of sixteen. This novel is framed as a conversation with Pheoby Watson, during which the protagonist recounts shooting her rabies-infected husband. Its title follows the line “They seemed to be staring at the dark” while the protagonist is sheltered from a hurricane with her lover Tea Cake. For 10 points, name this novel about Janie Crawford by Zora Neale Hurston.
tossups.answer: Their Eyes Were Watching God <RK, Long Fiction>

tossups.question: Michael Chandler and Christopher Lalonde’s studies of this practice among First Nations suggests that it is “hedged” against by “cultural continuity.” The classification of this practice as “monomania” was dismissed by a thinker who studied the “different aptitude” of countries for it. That thinker considered this practice an example of a “sui generis” phenomenon and suggested that “free inquiry” led to it being more common among (*) Protestants than Catholics. Except among Asian-Americans, the frequency of this practice in the US is about three times higher for men than for women. Altruistic, egoistic, and anomic motivations for this practice were distinguished by a pioneering French sociologist. For 10 points, name this practice studied by Émile Durkheim (“ay-MEEL dur-KEM”) whose historical varieties include suttee (“SUH-tee”).
tossups.answer: suicide [or equivalents like killing oneself; prompt on death; do not accept or prompt on “murder”] <WA, Social Science: Socio/Anthro>

tossups.question: The Buddha is often shown raising one of these objects in an action called “fearless” or abhaya during encounters with an elephant. A motto called the Parasparopagraho Jivanam (“PAR-us-PAR-oh-PA-gruh-ho JEE-vuh-num”) is often found below one of these objects in a symbol adopted on the 2500th anniversary of the nirvana of Mahavira. This is the most common object that, prior to a Hindu wedding, is decorated with mehndi or (*) tattoos. These objects are used to make mudras. One of them with a wheel on it is used both as a symbol of ahimsa and of Jainism in general. In many Indian religions, these body parts are manipulated during meditation into wheel-like shapes to channel energy. For 10 points, give these body parts used to make gestures.
tossups.answer: hands [prompt on arms until “ahimsa” is read] <WA, Religion>

tossups.question: This city returned to its historic Republican control in 2013 after its mayor was caught sexually assaulting veterans at a conference on sexual assault in the military, after which he resigned in disgrace. Bob Filner was mayor of this city, where Sarah Jacobs’ primary campaign was funded by a donation of 1.5 million dollars by her grandfather Irvin, the head of local industrial giant Qualcomm. In Congress, Darrell Issa (“ICE-uh”) long represented this city. Trucks enter this city from the south via (*) Otay Mesa (“OH-tie MAY-suh”), the southern terminus of highway I-5. Comic-Con takes place in this city. It is home to the busiest port of entry in the US, which links El Chaparral with San Ysidro and is the site of more ICE deportations than any other such port. For 10 points, name this city across the border from Tijuana, the southernmost on the California coast.
tossups.answer: San Diego <WA, Other Academic>

tossups.question: An archaeologist from this country found massive statues of Aramean royalty at the site of Tell Halaf, which he spent much of his life excavating. Another archaeologist from this country funded his expeditions by selling gunpowder to the Russian army during the Crimean War. That archaeologist from this country destroyed much of his most famous discovery due to his fondness for using dynamite to excavate. The (*) Pergamon Altar is controversially kept in a museum in this country’s capital. Another archaeologist from this country targeted a mound at Hisarlik for excavation and found the Death Mask of Agamemnon. For 10 points, Troy was excavated by Heinrich Schliemann, an archaeologist from what country?
tossups.answer: Germany [or Federal Republic of Germany or Bundesrepublik Deutschland] <JM, Ancient/Archaeology>

tossups.question: A politically-conscious poet known as the “nightingale of” this country wrote the collection The Golden Threshold. In the 1960s, a group of poets in this country known as the Hungry Generation were visited by Ernesto Cardenal and Octavio Paz. A poet wrote a song promising “Victory, victory, victory to” the “dispenser of [this country’s] destiny,” whom he calls the “ruler of the minds of all people.” That poet beckoned “Father, let [this country] awake” in a place “Where the (*) mind is without fear and the head is held high” in a poem from a Nobel-Prize-winning collection with an introduction by W. B. Yeats (“yates”). That collection from this country begins “Thou hast made me endless, such is thy pleasure” and is translated as Song Offerings. For 10 points, name this home country of the Bengali poet Rabindranath Tagore.
tossups.answer: India [or Republic of India; or Bhārat Gaṇarājya] (The first poet is Sarojini Naidu.) <RK, Poetry>

tossups.question: Like rhenium and gold, this element forms a heptafluoride that is a strong oxidizing agent. This is the heavier element taken up by a symporter that is inhibited by the pertechnetate (“per-TEK-nuh-tate”) ion. This element’s methyl derivative reacts with a square planar iridium complex in the first step of the Cativa process. One isotope of this element decays by electron capture to tellurium-123, a reaction used in SPECT imaging. An ionic compound of this element and silver is used in both cloud seeding and photographic film. The (*) triatomic form of this element reacts with starch to form a purple complex, a phenomenon that is used in a popular clock reaction and Lugol’s test. Of the elements that are diatomic at STP, this element is the heaviest. For 10 points, name this halogen that is added to salt to prevent goiter.
tossups.answer: iodine [prompt on I] <RN, Chemistry>

tossups.question: The defeat of this group is commemorated by the Lajkonik (“lie-CON-eek”) festival, which remembers a war in which this group counted their kills by filling nine sacks with right ears. King Béla IV of Hungary weakened his position before a battle with this group by expelling the Cumans, who had themselves fled this group’s advances. A crusade against this group was proposed after their victory at the Battle of (*) Legnica (“leg-NEET-sah”). The death of a leader of this group caused their general Subotai to retreat from Vienna in order to elect a new one. Those elections, the kurultai, were described in a Secret History of this group. This group was founded by a man with the birth name Temüjin. For 10 points, name this group that invaded Europe under Batu Khan and were founded by Genghis Khan.
tossups.answer: Mongols [accept Tatars or Golden Horde or Ulus of Jochi; accept The Secret History of the Mongols; do not accept or prompt on “Kipchaks”] <ML, European History>

tossups.question: In 2019, this constant was redefined such that the fine-structure constant equals [read slowly] “this quantity, times c, times e-squared, all over two times Planck’s constant.” The product of this quantity with the speed of light equals approximately 377 ohms. This constant’s units are equivalent to [read slowly] “seconds squared, divided by farads times meters,” as can be shown by rearranging Maxwell’s formula. This constant can be experimentally measured by finding the force between two wires of known length, current, and separation. It used to equal exactly (*) 4 pi times 10-to-the-negative-7 henries per meter. The current enclosed by a loop of wire, times this constant, equals the line integral of the B-field along that loop by Ampère’s circuit law. For 10 points, name this constant symbolized “mu-nought” that gives the ability of a vacuum to support a magnetic field.
tossups.answer: magnetic permeability [or vacuum permeability; or permeability of free space; or mu-nought; accept magnetic constant until “constant” is read, but prompt after; prompt on mu until “mu-nought” is read; do not accept or prompt on “permittivity”] <WA, Physics>

tossups.question: Mohsin Hamid (“MO-sin HA-mid”) organized his past nonfiction into sections on life, art, and politics in a 2014 collection whose title riffs on one of this author’s works. This author of an analysis of Wilhelm Jensen’s novel Gradiva is the subject of a “Tribute” by the poet H.D. about her time with him. He used the character of Olympia to further an idea developed by Ernst Jentsch (“yench”) in an essay on E. T. A. Hoffman’s “The Sandman.” Detective fiction likely inspired this author of an essay on “The (*) Uncanny” to write about a boy who imagines a pack of wolves outside his window called the “Wolf Man.” An idea put forth by this author was inspired by a character who murders his father Laius in an Ancient Greek play, and was believed to be innate to all boys. For 10 points, name this Austrian thinker whose ideas influenced psychoanalytic literary criticism.
tossups.answer: Sigmund Freud [or Sigismund Schlomo Freud] (Mohsin Hamid’s book is Discontent and its Civilizations.) <RK, Misc Lit>

tossups.question: A leader of this [emphasize] American movement lost credibility when he asked his followers to throw their fancy clothes into one of his “Bonfires of the Vanities,” then led by example by taking off his pants to do so; that man was James Davenport. Historian Sydney Ahlstrom compared this movement to Philipp Spener’s (“SHPAY-nur’s”) contemporary work in Germany. One of its leaders wrote an account of his “Surprising Work” in Northampton. Many “Old (*) Light–New Light” schisms occurred due to this movement, whose black devotees included Phyllis Wheatley. A speech from this movement compares listeners to a spider held over a fire. Itinerant figures active in this movement include Gilbert Tennent and George Whitefield (“WIT-field”). Jonathan Edwards also led, for 10 points, what religious revival that swept the mid-18th-century American colonies?
tossups.answer: First Great Awakening [prompt on Great Awakening; prompt on revival until it is read] <WA, US History>

tossups.question: Since this artwork is found next to the Church of Saint Agnes designed by one of its artist’s rivals, one of its figures is often said to be shielding its eyes from the architectural horror of the church. That figure in this artwork is a Native American who lies on top of a pile of coins. Another of this work’s title figures is an old man whose head is covered by a cloth, symbolizing the fact that a certain (*) source was unknown at the time. A copy of the Pamphili family obelisk protrudes from this sculpture in the Piazza Navona, which allegorizes bodies found on Asia, America, Africa, and Europe. For 10 points, name this fountain sculpted by Gian Lorenzo Bernini that personifies the Nile, Danube, Ganges, and Rio de la Plata.
tossups.answer: Fountain of the Four Rivers [or Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi] <RR, Painting/Sculpture>

tossups.question: This place is not Thebes, but an epic poem by Statius was the first to relate a story in which a “Carpathian seer” tells a woman to take the poem’s title hero to this place. Because a goddess who shares her name with this place fought on Zeus’s side in the Titanomachy (“Titan-AW-muh-kee”), her children Zelos, Cratos, Bia, and Nike are always near Zeus. The spread of a Greek belief regarding this place is tracked by numismatic findings of one-sixth of a drachma. Inviolable (*) oaths were sworn at this place by the Olympians. Thetis held her son by the heel while attempting to dip her son into this place and grant him invincibility. To ensure passage across this place, ancient Greeks buried the dead with an obol, or coin, under their tongue. Charon ferries people across, for 10 points, what river that surrounds the underworld?
tossups.answer: Styx [or The River Styx; prompt on underworld or Hades] <AA, Myths/Legends>

tossups.question: It’s not in South America, but several states that bordered this colony allied with Admiral Cornelis Jol (“cor-NAY-liss YOLE”), who briefly annexed it as part of the Groot Desseyn (“kh’ROTE duh-SIGN”) plan by the Netherlands. This colony was greatly enlarged in the 1700s when it annexed the lands of the Ovimbundu people. A neighbor of this colony invaded it in Operation Savannah. This colony initially had a separate constituent part named for the port of (*) Benguela (“ben-GWAY-lah”). Holden Roberto’s FNLA and Agostinho Neto’s (“ah-goosh-TEEN-yoo NET-oo’s”) MPLA fought for the independence of this colony, which was the primary source of slaves for Brazilian plantations controlled by the same colonial power. For 10 points, name this Portuguese colony whose successor state’s capital is Luanda.
tossups.answer: Portuguese Angola <JM, World History>

tossups.question: According to a namesake principle of functional analysis, pointwise-bounded linear operators on a Banach (“BAH-nuck”) space have this type of boundedness. A sequence of functions converges in the infinity norm if the sequence has this type of convergence, which is defined by the existence of a natural number capital N that depends only on epsilon, not on a point x. This type of continuity implies pointwise continuity. The CDF of a distribution named for this word is (*) linear between its two parameters, and its variance equals b-minus-a squared over twelve. Computing a probability using this distribution is often equivalent to finding the area of a rectangle because the density function is the constant function “one over b-minus-a.” For 10 points, rolling a die exemplifies the discrete form of what distribution in which each outcome has the same probability of occurring?
tossups.answer: uniform [or uniformly; or uniform distribution; or uniform convergence; or uniform continuity] <NC, Math>

tossups.question: This director’s first film overlays shots from the Japanese film International Secret Police with dialogue about the search for the world’s best egg salad recipe. An office divider was placed on stage to shoot a scene from another of this director’s films in which two characters are simultaneously speaking in their respective therapist’s offices, a suggestion by cinematographer Gordon Willis. The role of Linda in this director’s adaptation of his Broadway play (*) Play it Again, Sam was his first casting of an actress who, in a later film, played a quirky singer who performs “Seems Like Old Times” before the curtains close. In that comedy by this director, the neurotic Jewish comedian Alvy Singer tries to understand why he broke up with the title woman played by Diane Keaton. For 10 points, name this director of Annie Hall.
tossups.answer: Woody Allen <WA, Other Arts: Film>

tossups.question: At a play’s opening, a Master of Ceremonies says he needs a “really big guy” to imitate one of these events after having the actors pick out characters and masks. During one of these events, a character notes that “man is no more but such a poor, bare, forked animal as thou art” and tears off his clothes upon seeing a madman who sings “Childe Roland to the dark tower came.” During one of these events from the first scene of another play, Gonzalo requests “an (*) acre of barren ground: long heath, brown furze.” In Act 3 of King Lear, the title character wanders the Heath with Kent and his Fool during one of these events. One of these events opens a play set on an “Enchanted Isle” that was once ruled by the witch Sycorax (“SICK-uh-rax”) and is home to the slave Caliban. For 10 points, what sort of event is conjured by Prospero and Ariel to begin a Shakespeare play?
tossups.answer: storms [accept tempests or The Tempest or A Tempest or Une Tempête] <RK, Drama>

tossups.question: R. G. Collingwood’s book The Principle of Art draws heavily on the aesthetics that an idealist thinker from this country presented in four lessons he wrote for the inauguration of Rice University, titled The Essence of Aesthetic. Another philosopher from this country postulated a person who creates an “articulating principle” that synthesizes the ideology of different classes, termed an “organic intellectual.” That Marxist from this country coined the term (*) “subaltern” in the context of his discussion of cultural hegemony. An exhortation to “restore” this present-day country “to liberty” from foreign powers ends a book by another man from here which argues that, for most rulers, it is better to be feared than loved. For 10 points, name this country home to the author of The Prince, Niccolò Machiavelli.
tossups.answer: Italy [or Italia or Italian Republic] (The first two men discussed are Benedetto Croce and Antonio Gramsci.) <ML, Phil/Thought>

tossups.question: Epithelioid examples of these cells fuse to form multi-nucleated giant cells in granulomatous (“gran-yuh-LOM-uh-tuss”) diseases like sarcoidosis. These cells use heme oxygenase to generate biliverdin, a critical step in red blood cell breakdown in the spleen. Whether these cells metabolize arginine to ornithine is used to categorize them into M1 and M2 subtypes, and like their precursors, they express CD68. Alveolar (“al-vee-OH-lur”) examples of these cells are reservoirs for (*) Mycobacterium tuberculosis. These cells are often characterized by the tissue they reside in, and are also known as microglia in the CNS and Kupffer cells in the liver. Like dendritic cells and B cells, these cells present antigens to T cells. For 10 points, name these cells produced by the differentiation of monocytes, whose name means “big eater.”
tossups.answer: macrophages [prompt on white blood cells or leukocytes or monocytes] <RN, Biology: Immuno>  If the game is tied at this point, report to your tournament director for tiebreaker instructions.   Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: This algorithmic technique is generally useful for solving constraint satisfaction problems, like Sudoku, graph coloring, or arranging eight queens on a board such that no two queens attack one another. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Edsger W. Dijkstra (“DIKE-stra”) [or Edsger Wybe Dijkstra]
search [or searching; accept depth-first search or binary search or linear search; prompt on finding or traversal; prompt on DFS] <RK, Computer Science>
parts: Name this technique that reverts to the previous recursion level after pruning candidate solutions that don’t meet a constraint. This technique can have catastrophic exponential behavior in greedy regular expressions.
This computer scientist devised a backtracking algorithm to solve the eight queens problem. When modified with a heuristic, an algorithm invented by this man is known as the A-star algorithm.

Dijkstra’s solution uses the depth-first algorithm for this task. For a sorted list, the binary algorithm for this task runs in big-O of log-n time, so it is more efficient than the linear algorithm for this task, which has to check each item.

bonuses.leadin: One of the first of these events was regularly hosted in the Hôtel de Rambouillet (“rom-boo-YAY”) by the socialite Catherine de Vivonne (“kaht-REEN duh vee-VUN”). For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: The Republic of Letters [or La République des Lettres or Respublica literaria; accept News from the Republic of Letters]
philosophes (“fee-luh-SOFFS”) [do not accept or prompt on “philosophers”] <WA, European History>
parts: Give this term for intellectual gatherings in the 18th and 19th centuries often hosted by women, particularly in Paris and London.

Salons were part of this broader international community named for its primary method of correspondence across long distances. Intellectual Pierre Bayle (“bail”) published a periodical titled for “News From” this community, whose name was coined by Francesco Barbaro.
This French term collectively denotes the leading thinkers of the Enlightenment, many of whom participated actively in the Republic of Letters. Voltaire is considered one of these people.

bonuses.leadin: A poet with this surname maintained a rivalry with Eliza Haywood and drunkenly murdered James Sinclair during a nighttime walk. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Savage [accept Richard Savage or Walter Savage Landor; do not accept or prompt on “Landor”]
wandering [accept The Wanderer or “I wandered lonely as a cloud”] <RK, Poetry>
parts: Give this name. A poet who had this [emphasize] middle name wrote a series of Imaginary Conversations with noted historical figures and evoked “A night of memories and of sighs / I consecrate to thee” in the poem “Rose Aylmer.”
This author used his biography The Life of Mr. Richard Savage as the basis of a famed chapter of his collection Lives of the Most Eminent English Poets.

Richard Savage’s most celebrated work is likely his five-canto poem titled for a man who performs this action. The speaker of William Wordsworth’s poem “Daffodils” recounts performing this action “lonely as a cloud.”

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Forrest Myers’ 1969 piece Moon Museum, a tiny ceramic wafer designed to be attached to the Apollo 12 Lunar Module. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: cars [or automobiles; accept Ford Model A; accept Automobile Tire Print] <RK, Painting/Sculpture>
parts: This artist’s contribution to the piece was a version of his signature that strongly resembles a penis. He made silkscreen prints out of his studio, the Factory.
For the “museum,” Claes Oldenburg (“CLASS OLD-en-burkh”) scribbled a crude rendition of this cultural icon, whose first appearance was in the 1928 production Steamboat Willie.

A pattern resembling circuitry was created for the museum by John Chamberlain, whose best-known artworks are assemblages created from these objects. Robert Rauschenberg created a 24-foot-wide “print” by having John Cage use one of these objects.

bonuses.leadin: Defects in the synthesis of this molecule, such as mutations in the enzymes AGAT and GAMT, or in the transporter, SLC6A8, can lead to neurological and muscular deficiencies. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: creatine (“CREE-uh-teen”) [do not accept or prompt on “creatinine” – ask team to spell if necessary]
parts: Name this molecule synthesized in the liver and kidney from glycine, arginine, and methionine. Its namesake kinase is a common marker of muscle degradation.

Phosphocreatine is vital in muscle and nervous tissue because it can be used to rapidly regenerate this nucleotide, the energy currency of the cell. Glycolysis generates two net molecules of this substance.
The first step of creatine biosynthesis generates ornithine as a byproduct, which is fed into a cycle named for this molecule that is used to dispose of nitrogenous waste from protein breakdown.

bonuses.leadin: This artist met his second wife, the pianist “Lil” Hardin, while they were both members of “King” Oliver’s Creole Jazz Band. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Louis Armstrong [prompt on Louis; prompt on Ella and Louis]
Great American Songbook <RK, Other Arts: Music>
parts: Name this musician who sits in a folding chair next to Ella Fitzgerald on the cover of a 1956 album backed by the Oscar Peterson Quartet, titled for “Ella and” this person.
Ella and Louis included multiple tracks composed by this man, including his “A Foggy Day.” The duo later made an album covering songs from his opera Porgy and Bess.

Ella and Louis is credited with rekindling interest in pieces from the US collectively referred to by this three-word term. Many pieces in this informal collection were composed in Tin Pan Alley or for musical theater.

bonuses.leadin: The University of Pennsylvania’s Adam Grant argues that people who exhibit a mix of these traits can have advantages as salespeople. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: extroverted AND introverted (Adam Grant’s idea is that of an “ambivert.”)
neuroticism [accept The Neurotic Personality; prompt on neurosis] <WA, Social Science: Psych>
parts: Give these two personality traits that are represented by the contrasting “E” and “I” in the Myers–Briggs classification.
This psychologist, who popularized the terms “extrovert” and “introvert,” also theorized a hidden aspect of personality called the “shadow.”

Extraversion is one of the five major components of the Big Five model, along with openness, conscientiousness, and agreeableness. The fifth is this trait, whose effects on personality were studied in an influential book by Karen Horney (“HORN-eye”).

bonuses.leadin: A legend from medieval Europe claims that a number of “red” examples of these people in the steppes would one day invade Europe, and may be based on the real-life Khazars. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Gog AND Magog [or Yajuj AND Majuj]
parts: Name these people. A legendary example of these people may have been a doorman to Pontius Pilate (“pilot”) and was cursed to be a nomad until the Second Coming.

Similar to the “Red Jews” are this pair from Abrahamic tradition, who were identified with Scythians by Josephus, and with the people of Meshech and Tubal by the Bible. Islamic myths hold that Alexander the Great built his namesake “gates” to keep these figures north of the Caucasus mountains.
The story of Gog and Magog appears in the namesake book of this Old Testament prophet, who experiences visions of God’s chariot and a valley of dry bones.

bonuses.leadin: Name these alcoholic beverages found throughout Latin America, for 10 points each.
parts: This hard alcohol is primarily made in Mexico, where it is distilled from the blue agave (“uh-GAH-vay”) plant, unlike mezcal, which is made from any agave. It shares its name with a city in Jalisco (“ha-LEESE-ko”).
This delicious Brazilian cocktail is typically made with cachaça (“ka-SHA-sa”) rum, sugar, and lime.

In the highlands of the Andes, one may drink this corn-based beer during such festivals as the Yamor festival of Ecuador. This drink’s non-alcoholic variants, such as a sweet “morada” variety, are served at many restaurants.

bonuses.leadin: An anthology of plays in this genre by Donald Keene is titled for the stock character of the “blue-eyed” servant Tarokaja. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: commedia dell’arte [prompt on comedy of the profession] <RK, Drama>
parts: Give this genre of Japanese comedy that developed out of a form known as “monkey music.” This farcical genre, whose name translates to “mad words,” was usually performed during interludes between Noh plays.
The comic dialogue of kyōgen contrasted with the gravity of Noh, which used these props to convey emotion. Greek theatre is often symbolized by two of these props expressing tragedy and comedy.

Because they were contemporaneous and both included stock characters, kyōgen is often compared to this genre of Italian theatre. Plays in this genre often featured the pedantic Il Dottore and the greedy Pantalone.

bonuses.leadin: A field of chemistry denoted by this color emphasizes atom economy, or maximizing the number of atoms in the reactants that appear in the final product. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this color that appears in the flame test of boron. It is also the color of the pigment chromium(III) oxide, or viridian.
The peroxide process produces this molecule without the generation of sodium chloride as a byproduct. This molecule is used to reduce carbonyls (“car-bo-NEELS”) in the Wolff–Kishner reduction.

Another success of green chemistry is the use of E. coli to produce a propane-based molecule of this type. When these molecules are vicinal (“VISS-uh-null”), they can be cleaved by periodic (“pur-eye-ODD-ick”) acid to produce two carbonyls.

bonuses.leadin: During this event, tycoon Thomas Scott claimed that people should try a “rifle diet” to get them to stop protesting low wages. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Great Railroad Strike of 1877 [prompt on Railroad Strike; do not accept or prompt on “Great Railroad Strike of 1922”]
parts: Name this event, also called the “Great Upheaval.” Thomas Scott’s advice on using the army to end it led to the passage of the Posse Comitatus Act and led to massacres in Pittsburgh, Scranton, and Reading (“RED-ing”).
This president suppressed the Great Railroad Strike of 1877 one year after being awarded the presidency despite losing the popular vote in a compromise that required him to end Reconstruction.
The Great Railroad Strike began in this state, where the Battle of Blair Mountain would later see miners face off against company-owned militias.

bonuses.leadin: Bill Clinton fiercely advocated for China’s entry into this organization, which occurred in December 2001. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: intellectual property [or IP; accept patents; do not accept or prompt on “property”] <WA, Other Academic>
parts: Name this international organization founded in 1995 that sets the rules of commerce. It replaced an earlier framework called GATT.
WTO rules allow countervailing duties to be imposed on parties that engage in this practice of selling goods in a foreign market for significantly less than “fair market value.”

The WTO’s Uruguay Round dealt with this commodity, which is subject to the Berne Three-Step Test in several international treaties. In the US, most cases brought before the Federal Circuit concern this commodity.

bonuses.leadin: These people disproportionately came from the Hoa (“hwah”) people, a group of Overseas Chinese. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Vietnamese boat people [or Thuyền nhân Việt Nam]
Cambodia [or Kingdom of Cambodia; accept Kampuchea or Cambodge]
Mahathir Mohamad [prompt on Mohamad] (He is the Prime Minister of Malaysia.) <WA, World History>
parts: Give the generic term for refugees who fled Vietnam in makeshift craft after the Vietnam War ended in 1975.
Vietnam’s border tensions with this Southeast Asian country exacerbated the exodus of boat people. A 1979 Vietnamese invasion overthrew this country’s Khmer Rouge government.

As Prime Minister of another country in the 1980s and ’90s, this man established a “shoo or shoot” policy denying boat people entry into his country. More recently, he returned to office in 2018 as his country’s first PM to not come from the Barisan National or its predecessor, the Alliance Party.

bonuses.leadin: T. S. Eliot claimed that these two authors “divide the world between them. There is no third.” For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Dante AND William Shakespeare [accept Dante Alighieri in place of “Dante”]
Thomas Carlyle (That novel is Sartor Resartus.) <RK, Misc Lit>
parts: Name these two authors. The description of a feud between the Montecchi and the Cappelletti by one of these authors in his epic poem Inferno might have inspired the other to feature the families in his play Romeo and Juliet.
This Yale literary critic positioned Dante as the “second center” in relation to Shakespeare and began his enumeration of a “Western Canon” with essays on the two writers.

A lecture championing Dante and Shakespeare as examples of “The Hero as Poet” was delivered by this British author. His only novel examines the life of a scholar who studies the “philosophy of clothes.”

bonuses.leadin: A widely rejected theory links the language of this ancient kingdom to South India’s Dravidian language family. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Indus River Valley [accept Indus Valley Civilization]
parts: Name this kingdom in modern Western Iran whose king, Shutruk-Nahhunte, took the stelae (“STEE-lee”) of the Babylonian kings Naram-Sin and Hammurabi back to his capital of Susa during a 12th-century BC invasion of the Kassite Dynasty.
Elam was one of the main trading partners of a civilization in this river valley in modern-day Pakistan, which was based around cities like Mohenjo-Daro and Harappa.
Susa was later sacked in the 7th century BC by this Neo-Assyrian ruler and successor of Esarhaddon. He built a massive royal library and wrote a history of his conquest of, among other places, Egypt.

bonuses.leadin: A 2007 book by Christoph Luxenberg about this book drew criticism for its sweeping theological conclusions based on purported Syriac etymologies. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: the Qur’an [or al-Qur’an; or the Holy Koran, etc.]
the belief that 72 virgins are awarded in heaven [accept equivalents mentioning 72 virgins; prompt on virgins] <WA, Religion>
parts: Name this book that many Western scholars nonetheless believe draws heavily on Syriac liturgy. This book is divided into chapters called suras.
The Syriac liturgy that Luxenberg analyzes is written in a variant of this Semitic language, which is believed to have been the language that the historical Jesus spoke in everyday life.

Luxenberg’s book includes the oft-repeated argument that this belief regarding jannah relies on a mistranslation of the word houri (“hoo-ree”), which Luxenberg suggests means “grape” or “raisin.” A description is fine.

bonuses.leadin: The sixth book of these compositions contains a piece titled for the surname of the composer’s friend Niels Gade (“GAY-thuh”), to whom he dedicated his only piano sonata, which is in E minor. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: suites [accept Lyric Suite or Holberg Suite; accept orchestral suite or suite for string orchestra] <WA, Classical/Opera>
parts: Name this group of 66 piano compositions. Its first book includes a “Watchman’s Song” and begins with an “Arietta.”
This Norwegian composer of the Lyric Pieces also wrote “In the Hall of the Mountain King.”

Grieg orchestrated four of his Lyric Pieces, including the “March of the Dwarfs,” into one of these collections. Another of these collections by Grieg ends with a rigaudon (“ree-go-DAWN”) and commemorates the birth of the playwright Ludvig Holberg.

bonuses.leadin: Examples of these devices used in the US typically use light water as moderators. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: nuclear reactors [prompt on nuclear power plants or reactors; accept, but DO NOT REVEAL, fission reactors]
liquid metals [or liquidized metals; accept liquid sodium; prompt on metals] <WA, Physics>
parts: Name these devices into which control rods are inserted in order to regulate the rate of their primary processes. Historically, these devices were known as piles.
Nuclear reactors obtain electric power via this process, in which one atom breaks into one or more smaller atoms. This process was also exploited in the first nuclear bombs.

High power density in nuclear reactors can be achieved by using coolants made of these highly conductive substances. Those so-called “fast reactors” utilizing these substances were developed for use in submarines.

bonuses.leadin: Tao Lin’s second novel, which concerns a relationship between characters named Haley Joel Osment and Dakota Fanning, is titled for this novelist. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Richard Yates (Lin’s novel is Richard Yates.)
parts: Name this American author who included imaginary interior dialogue in a novel depicting the breakdown of the middle-class couple Frank and April in 1950s suburbia, titled Revolutionary Road.

Revolutionary Road ends with Frank mourning April after she dies trying to perform this action. The director of St. Cloud’s Orphanage, Dr. Wilbur Larch, performs this service in John Irving’s The Cider House Rules.
After Lafe tricks her into having sex, Dewey Dell repeatedly struggles to get an abortion in As I Lay Dying, a novel by this Mississippi author.
